Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Large: Collaborative: The Science and Applications of Crypto-Currency

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Crypto-currencies and smart contracts are a new wave of disruptive technology that will shape the future of money and financial transactions. Today, crypto-currencies are a billion-dollar market, and hundreds of companies are entering this space, promising exciting new markets and eco-systems. Unfortunately, usage of crypto-currencies outstrips our understanding. Currently most crypto currencies rely on heuristic designs without a solid appreciation of the necessary security properties, or any formal basis upon which strong assurance of such properties might be achieved.

This work aims to establish a rigorous scientific foundation for crypto-currencies. To achieve this, this work blends cryptography, game theory, programming languages, and systems security techniques. Expected outcomes include new crypto-currency designs with provable security properties, financially enforceable cryptographic protocols whose security properties are backed by enforceable payments in case of a breach, smart contract systems that are easy to program and formally verifiable, as well as high-assurance systems for storing and handling high-value crypto-currencies and transactions. The project will provide solutions to some of the most difficult and important technical questions surrounding the current digital-money revolution. The investigators will organize a crypto-currency speaker series that will bring together technologists, economists, social scientists, and policy-makers to foster collaborations that will shape the future of digital currencies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we aimed to establish a rigorous scientific foundation for crypto-currencies. To this end, we have achieved numerous accomplishments and our work has led to significant impact. First, we developed a new scientific foundation for large-scale distributed consensus. In a decentralized environment, we would like to scale up blockchain constructions to thousands or even millions of nodes, and yet be able to provide fast confirmation and high throughput. It is well-understood that the Nakamoto consensus protocol that underlies Bitcoin is unlikely the longer-term desired solution due to its slowness, low throughput, and energy waste. In a sequence of works, we developed a new mathematical foundation for large-scale consensus. We were able to mathematically demonstrate why large-scale consensus raises new robust requirements that depart from classical consensus. We proposed various consensus protocols with provable security, which fundamentally solved the scalability and efficiency challenges for large-scale consensus. We also suggested provably secure protocols for proof-of-stake, which fundamentally overcomes the energy waste problem. We developed new programming language techniques for cryptocurrencies, including higher-order symbolic execution techniques for contract verification and refutation.  We explored the direction of incentive compatible decentralized systems, and were able to better understand the economics behind “cryptocurrency mining”, and propose game-theoretically secure consensus protocols. We also developed new techniques for securing smart contracts. We have published and disseminated our research results at major conferences in cryptography, security, distributed systems, and programming languages. 

 

Our work led to significant impact in the cryptocurrency industry. We created a new blockchain initiative called “The Initiative For Cryptocurrencies & Contracts (IC3)”. Through a series of retreats and boot-camps, IC3 created a bridge between academic research and blockchain companies. We were able to facilitate the technology transfer of various cutting-edge research results (including some of our own) into real-world adoption. 

 

This project has helped to train various students and postdocs. Several of them have graduated and continued onto tenure-track faculty positions or research positions in companies. 

 

Besides the IC3 events, the PIs also helped to organize other major academic events on blockchains. For example, we helped to co-organize a Simons program “Proofs, Consensus, and Decentralizing Society”, as well as a distributed consensus workshop affiliated with the simons program. We organized a blockchain workshop at the FOCS conference, and helped to co-organize a blockchain workshop at CRYPTO. The PIs also organized winter-schools on blockchains joint with Tsinghua University, and invited many international experts to speak. The PIs also gave various invited talks and tutorials, e.g., invited talks at RWC, various universities such as Berkeley, Stanford, MIT, CMU, Duke, keynote talks at Asiacrypt, ISC, invited talks at DIMACS workshops and numerous major blockchain events. 

 

In terms of educational efforts, the PIs developed new courses on distributed consensus and blockchains. The PIs have also incorporated blockchain and cryptocurrency into undergraduate-level distributed systems and cryptography courses. PI Shi also has a new textbook “Foundations of Distributed Consensus and Blockchains”, and the first draft is now available.
